image_matrix.caption: I went on a 10 day climbing excursion in the Grand Tetons in 1987, guided by the Exum Mountain Guides. We climbed the Grand Teton (13,770 feet), Middle Teton (12,805 feet), and Mount Moran (12,605 feet). It turned out that this proved good preparation for my guided climbs in the Andes with the American Alpine Institute in 1989-1991. Google Earth image.
A sundown scene looking west. Courtesy of Go GrandTetons.
A view of the South, Middle, and Grand Tetons.
On the top of the Grand with two members of the climbing team. Preparation and the climb lasted four days.
A look over at Middle Teton as sunrise casts a golden glow.
On the top of Middle Teton with the Grand behind. This was a two day climb.
Mt. Moran. The vertical Black Dike, as it's known, is a basalt intrusion. Courtesy of FLICKR.
Another view of Mt. Moran. Our route was to the left of the Black Dike.
On the top of Moran. Our guide is on the right. This was a climb of three days.

shortname: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.
name: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Ecuador in January, 1989.

image_matrix.caption: A view from 30,000 feet at the main Ecuador peaks. Loren McIntyre.
A jet landing at the old Mariscal Sucre passes right above a residential neighborhood. The guy is using a flame torch to burn weeds, although he seems to be firing at the jet! Courtesy of Wiki.

Iñaquito is one of 55 parishes in the canton of Quito located towards the north of the city and near the old Mariscal Sucre. Our hotel was located here. There is a large concentration of malls in the area and the population is exceedingly wealthy relative to the rest of Quito. This is also home to a large international community, primarily Americans. Various mission agencies have their Ecuador headquarters here. Courtesy of GOQUITO.

The Ciudad Mitad del Mundo (Middle of the World City) is a tract of land owned by the prefecture of the province of Pichincha, Ecuador. It is located 16 miles north of the center of Quito. The grounds contain the Monument to the Equator, which highlights the exact location of the Equator from which the country takes its name; they also contain the Ethnographic Museum Middle of the Earth, a museum about the indigenous people ethnography of Ecuador. The 98 ft monument was constructed between 1979 and 1982 by Pichincha's Province Council to replace an older, smaller monument built by the Government of Ecuador in 1936. It is made of iron and concrete and covered with cut and polished andesite stone. The monument was built to commemorate the first Geodesic Mission of the French Academy of Sciences. It conducted experiments to test the flattening at the poles of the characteristic shape of the Earth, by comparing the distance between a degree meridian in the equatorial zone to another level measured in Sweden. The older monument was moved 4.3 miles to the town of CalaCali. Courtesy of Yee Wang.

The Otavalo market. Otavalo, capital of Otavalo canton, has a population largely made up of the Otavalo indigenous group. It has 39,354 inhabitants and sits at an elevation of 8,307 feet. It is surrounded by the peaks of Imbabura (15,190 feet), Cotacachi (16,388 ft)), and Mojanda (12,300 feet) volcanoes. The indigenous Otavalo people are famous for weaving textiles, usually made of wool, such as handmade blankets, tablecloths, and much more. Our climbing team visited on Saturday, the famous market day. Courtesy of GRAYLINE.

After spending the morning at the Otavalo market, we hiked through the hills of the town, crossed through fields and eucalyptus groves, and came to Lago San Pedro and had lunch at the restaurant of the Lago Pedro Hotel. Courtesy of INTHEKNOW.

The day after visiting Otavalo, we made our way to the Panecillo. El Panecillo (from Spanish panecillo small piece of bread) is a 650 foot high hill of volcanic-origin located between southern and central Quito. Its peak is at an elevation of 9,895 feet above sea level. The original name used by the aboriginal inhabitants of Quito was Yavirac. There was a temple on top of Yavirac where the Indians worshiped the sun until it was destroyed by the conquistadors. In 1976, the Spanish artist Agustín de la Herrán Matorras was commissioned to build a 150 foot tall stone monument of a Madonna on the top of Panecillo. Called \"Virgin of Panecillo\", it is made of seven thousand pieces of aluminum. The Virgin stands on top of a globe and is stepping on a snake, which is classic Madonna iconography. Less traditional are the wings. Locals claim that she is the only one in the world with wings like an angel. Courtesy of GOQUITO.
The Panecillo in the early evening with Antisana in the distance. Courtesy of NOTIMUNDO.
The Virgin on the top of the Panecillo. Courtesy of VISTA HERMOSA.
The Panecillo with Antisana to the east. Courtesy of ROUGHGUIDES.

The Church and Convent of St. Francis is a 16th-century Roman Catholic complex in Quito, Ecuador and fronts onto its namesake Plaza de San Francisco. The imposing edifice has the distinction of being the largest architectural ensemble among the historical structures of colonial Latin America and for this reason is sometimes known as \"El Escorial of the New World\". The style evolved over almost 143 years of construction (1537-1680) through earthquakes and changes in architectural styles. The Church houses the city's beloved Virgin of Quito (1734). Courtesy of GOECUADOR.

Santo Domingo Church borders the southern edge of Quito Old Town and stands over Santo Domingo Plaza. The church represents fascinating periods in Quito’s religious history, as it was constructed by Dominicans and modified by Italian priests. The church’s stately tower features Baroque architectural styling and a city clock. This colonial era Church is well known for its awe-inspiring collection of art, located in the Lady of the Rosary chapel and the church museum. There are magnificent works by noteworthy Quiteño artists, including carvings, reliefs, and stunning frescos. Also on display is the famous sculpture of the Virgin del Rosario (Our Lady of the Rosary) and fine examples of artworks from the Quito School of Art. Courtesy of VISTA HERMOSA.
La Ronda is a popular attraction in Old Quito, famous for its many shops and cafes, all with a Bohemian edge to them. Courtesy of GOECUADOR.
An 1805 map of the Inca town of Quito. Artist: Juan Pio Montufar.
Another painting of Quito, this from the mid-18th century. Artist: Miguel de Santiago
Another painting of Quito, this one dated 1850. Artist: Rafael Salas.
My new little friend in Quito (1989).

Pichincha is an active volcano outside Quito, Ecuador. This Edward Whymper woodcut of 1892 shows three of Whymper's guides near the summit. Whymper was a famous naturalist, climber, and artist who climbed extensively in the Alps and the Andes. In 1880, he was the first climber to ascend a high altitude peak, in this case Chimborazo (20,400'). His signature appears in the lower left corner. See the delightful accounts of his climbs and travels in Travels Amongst the Great Andes of the Equator. R. Villarreal Collection.
Pichincha volcano summit (15,700', 4790 m).
This photo captures the 1999 eruption of Pichincha Volcano. I stood on the summit 12 years before this! Courtesy of Wikipedia.

El Cayambe (18,996', 5790 m) sits northeast of Quito. Its distinction is that the equator lies right on its southern slopes. We got this close to the peak before the guides determined that the entire lower portion of the Whymper route had been obliterated by avalanches. We pushed on to Cotopaxi.
Upon our departure from El Cayambe, I found another little friend, this one walking her dog.
Original 1892 Whymper woodcut of a puma approaching Whymper's tent on El Cayambe at 14,462' (4408 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
On the descent of El Cayambe, one of the pack animals slipped and fell over a precipice into the void below. Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut. R. Villarreal Collection.
Base Camp on Cotopaxi -- the Jose Rivas hut at 15,500' (4720 m).
Cotopaxi (19,347', 5897 m).
Another view of the Cotopaxi summit, this one higher on the route.
Whymper wood engraving dated 1892 of the Cotopaxi summit crater. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the return from the fog choked Cotopaxi summit, the mists lift to reveal the rich Ecuadorian countryside.
More stunning views from the flanks of Cotopaxi.
And more.
A section of the valley walls surrounding Banos, a small town near Tungurahua peak. It resembles Yosemite Valley, with numerous waterfalls that cascade into the valley below.
On the way from Banos to the Tungurahua staging area to rent our pack animals.
Pack horse for lugging our gear to a refugio on the slopes of Tungurahua volcano (16,475', 5022 m); next day it was too windy to climb.
The Tungurahua hut at 13,000' (4000 m). The wind was blasting the next morning so viciously that we cancelled an attempt on the summit.
This same Tungurahua erupting in April, 2011; the beautiful town of Banos is off to the left.
Another picture of the eruption.
We're on the way to the Carrel hut on Chimborazo (in the distance). Photo taken from Guarandas.

1899 original halftone print of Chimborazo by The Werner Company. This image is from Guarandas, very near the spot where I took the picture in the previous image. In both, the Whymper route to the summit is out of sight, over the ridge on the left skyline. R. Villarreal Collection.
This wood-engraving hunting scene most likely was carried out in the area of the previous picture of Chimborazo, near Guarandas. It's another Whymper work dated 1885. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Louis Carrel hut on Chimborazo, at 15,912' (4850 m). Carrel was one of Whymper's climbing guides in Ecuador.
A look down to the Carrel hut on the way up to the Base Camp location of the Whymper hut.
The Whymper hut at 16,404' (5000 m). Courtesy Summit Post.
Close up views of the red cliffs and the Whymper Glacier. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.

An aerial approaching Chimborazo from the north side, looking south. Whymper climbed El Arenal (the plain of ashes and cinders) under the clouds to the right, and up to the base of the red cliffs. He then crossed to the left to the bottom of the smooth glacier leading to the summit and climbed directly up it to the top. This is known as the \"Whymper Route\" and is the route we followed. Courtesy of Loren McIntyre.

A view of Chimborazo from the Whymper hut. The route follows the ridge to the right. Once above the rock and ice outcropping in the center of the picture, the route traverses to the left skyline and follows the glacier to the summit.
On the top; I'm on the left with our Ecuadorian guide.
Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut as he and his guides try to erect their tent low on the slopes of Chimborazo. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another Whymper engraving showing climbers, at 17,450' (5319 m), above the site of today's Whymper hut as they work their way across the ridge outside camp. R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper's engraving of the scene higher on the route, at 18,500' (5640 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper engraving of the route as they close on the summit. R. Villarreal Collection.
An engraving by Edward Whymper of his first ascent of Chimborazo.

Louis Carrel contracted frostbite on the climb. A litter was rigged up and he was carried to the nearby town of Ambato for medical treatment Another 1892 woodcut by Edward Whymper. R. Villarreal Collection.

shortname: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.
name: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Bolivia in June, 1990, preceded by a visit to Machu Picchu.

image_matrix.caption: Cuzco, Peru. The Plaza de Armas is at the center in the photo. The present day buildings around the square have the old Inca structures for their foundations. The Almagro Expedition departed the city for Chile on July 3, 1535.
1888 wood engraving of a Cuzco street scene. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
A modern street scene today, this the alley of Hatun Rumiyoq. Courtesy Odyssei.
The city of Cuzco. Original 1875 Engraving by Edouard Riou. Scribner, Armstrong, Co. Publisher. R. Villarreal Collection.
Cuzco street scene in 1978. Some of these buildings pre-date the Conquest and are the original Inca structures. R. Villarreal Collection.
Street scene in Cuzco from a hotel balcony in 1989. These buildings haven't changed since the Conquest. R. Villarreal Collection.

Antique print, titled “A Bird’s Eye View of Cusco, a City in Peru and the Principal City of the Region and Province of the Same Name.” This engraving originates from Sebastian Munster’s “Cosmographia, Beschreibung aller Lender”. It is from the 1592 German edition, published in Basel by Henrichum Petri. Munster, a German cartographer, cosmographer, and Christian scholar is best known for “Cosmographia”, the earliest German description of the world, in six parts. R. Villarreal Collection.
Inca Temple of the Sun in Cuzco. 1994. The Temple was used by the Incas at the time of, and before, the Conquest. R. Villarreal Collection.
Rustic street scene in Cuzco in 2000. R. Villarreal Collection.

Cusco, Peru. From: 'De Nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld: of beschryving van America en 't Zuid-Land.', by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. (The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland, Containing the Origin of the Americans and South-landers, remarkable voyages thither, Quality of the Shores, Islands, Cities, Fortresses, Towns, Temples, Mountains, Sources, Rivers, Houses, the nature of Beasts, Trees, Plants and foreign Crops, Religion and Manners, Miraculous Occurrences, Old and New Wars: Adorned with Illustrations drawn from the life in America, and described by Arnoldus Montanus). The book was translated and published in England by the editor and map publisher John Ogilby under the title, America, Being an Accurate Description of the New World (1671). Ref: In the late 1630s, Holland attempted to reassert its claim over Brazil by establishing a series of forts along the coastline. One of the best-documented colonies was the expedition led by Prince Maurits of Nassau, who attempted to assemble an intellectual court in the New World. He brought with him a group of highly accomplished artists, mapmakers, and scientists to record the mysteries of Brazil. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. Artists and Engravers: Some references mention Bernard Picart as the engraver. We have not been able to verify this. Bernard Picart (1673-1733) was a French painter and engraver. Author: Arnoldus Montanus (c.1625–1683) was a Dutch teacher and author. He published books on theology, history, and geography. Original 1671 engraving. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Inca fortress of Sacsayhuaman sits on a hill on the northern border of Cusco. The Spanish, in a furious battle over several days, were finally able to overcome General Quizquiz and his warriors and take possession of it. R. Villarreal Collection.
A close-up view of the massive walls of Sacsayhuaman. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
This is the site of the water tower, the Muyumarca, which was located inside the Fortress. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
The serrated northeastern walls of Sacsayhuaman. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Massive Fortress wall stones. R. Villarreal Collection.
The northern wall of the Citadel. Courtesy of Diego Delso.
Another view of the northeastern walls of the Fortress. R. Villarreal Collection.
View of the walls near the water tower. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Citadel was an imposing collection of forts and storage areas. The steepness of the numerous walls of the several valleys made attacks by the Christians difficult to effect. Courtesy of Wiki.
One of the several forts within the boundaries of the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
A row of stairs within the Citadel. R. Villarreal Collection.
Strange structures on the hill side. Courtesy of TicketMachu.
Terraces viewed from and staircase. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another stairwell. R. Villarreal Collection.
La Paz, with Illimani in the distance (1991).
1931 original photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag of La Paz, with Illimani in the distance. R. Villarreal Collection.
Our llama arrieros load the animals for the hike into Condoriri and Pequeno Alpamayo.
Earth image of Condoriri, Pequeño Alpamayo, and Huayna Potosi locations.

Condoriri (18,530 feet). Since I was sick the first several days on this expedition, I did not attempt this peak. Two did though and our guide got them to the top of its distinctive summit. Courtesy of Wikipedia.
On the way to Alpamayo.
Pequeno Alpamayo (17,558', 5352 m).
A view to the west.
We inch our way up.
On the top.
On the top with a rope mate.
Cerro Huayna Potosi (19,968', 6086 m).
One rope team nears the summit, out of sight to the right.
We approach a small village on the way to Base Camp. Illimani in distance (21,122', 6438 m).
Above the little village.
Another view.
We near Base Camp.
On the summit.
Our descent down the mountain.

The Tiwanaku (or Tiahuanaco) complex, looking north. Tiahuanaco is a Pre-Colombian archaeological site in western Bolivia. It was the capital of an empire that extended into present-day Peru and Chile, flourishing from AD 300 to AD 1000. The temple complex of Kalasasaya is in the center of the scene. The following pictures show much of the present-day site.
Staircase and entrance door of the Kalasasaya Temple.
Interior walls of the Semi-subterranean Temple with the \"embedded heads\" on its walls.
Another view of the Semi-subterranean Temple courtyard.
The Ponce monolith in the Kalasasaya complex.
The Gateway of the Sun. It stands 10 feet high and 13 feet wide.

shortname: The Expedition to Argentina in January, 1991.
name: The Expedition to Argentina in January, 1991.

ikarus_data.name: The Expedition to Argentina in January, 1991.
ikarus_data.shortname: The Expedition to Argentina in January, 1991.

image_matrix.caption: Original 1888 wood engraving of Aconcagua, artist unknown. The view is east. Aconcagua was first climbed in 1897 over the western walls by Matthias Zurbriggen, a member of the expedition led by E. A. Fitzgerald. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
An original 1913 half-tone print of Aconcagua. The view is east. Creator: G.P. Putnam's and Sons. R. Villarreal Collection.
At the trailhead of the Rio de las Vacas for the first day of the hike towards the peak.
We cross the de las Vacas later the first day.
A stretch of the de las Vacas on our way to Camp II at Casa de la Piedra.
In the afternoon of the second day, we reach Casa de Piedra for our second camp; Aconcagua is in the distance. The view is west.
Our Camp at Casa de la Piedra. The first view of Aconcagua is from this point.
A climber checks out the stone \"house.\" Courtesy of mza com ar.
Hiking up the Relinchos Valley to Base Camp; Aconcagua on the left, Ameghino on the right.
More of the Relinchos Valley.
The Relinchos stream.
Somewhere in the Relinchos Valley.
Rest stop on the stream.
Approaching Base Camp.
Our Base Camp at 13,000' (4000 m).
An arriero at Base Camp.
Our pack animals.
Above nieves penitentes on the way to Camp I.
A look down the Relinchos River Valley from just below Camp I.
Camp I.
The hike to Camp II at the foot of the Polish Glacier.
Progress towards Camp II.
Getting close.
Camp II - taking a break.
More of Camp II.
The view of Mercedario in the east.
Another vista from Camp II.
And another.
Looking up the impressive Polish Glacier; our route is in the ice and snow to the left.
We left Camp II at 1 AM; here we are at the top of the Glacier looking down its expanse.

We leave our rest stop at the top of the Glacier and strike out for the summit; I'm the one behind the climber immediately in picture. Behind stretches the Relinchos Valley all the way to Casa de Piedra on the de las Vacas. This is one of the most highly sought-after photos of the route pioneered by the Poles in 1934 along their route up the eastern slopes of the great peak. R. Villarreal Collection.
Making steady progress.
One of the team has an upset stomach.
We keep moving higher.
The view to the southwest.

As we approach the summit, a look back down the ridge of our ascent. The rock pinnacles seen in A.26 are just to the left and below the end of the ice ridge. Farther to the left, the Relinchos Valley is in the near distance, with the de las Vacas river in the far distance.
A rest stop near the summit.
Cerro Mercedario (22,047', 6720 m), looking east, from high on Aconcagua.

We're there! I'm on the left.
22,834' (6960 m)
Team photo on the summit.
We descend by way of the Canaleta on the western slopes. A thousand feet lower we traverse around the northern slopes to the eastern side for the return back to Base.
To prevent my frostbitten toes from becoming wet, my friends carry me across the Rio de las Vacas.
Group shot back at Puente del Inca. Though my right toes and fingers were frostbitten, the climb was worth it.
